content.verbatim_text: Assignment clauses can become critical in a sale of business, acquisition or other similar transaction. Having an obligation to obtain consents for assigning contracts from present contract parties can complicate and potentially sidetrack the contemplated transaction. Failure to pay close attention to the language of the assignment clause while the contract is being negotiated may also create an opportunity for the nontransferring party to later extort concessions in return to its consent to the contract assignment.
content.plain_text: Assignment clauses are crucial in business sales, acquisitions, or similar transactions. Requiring consent from contract parties for assignment can complicate and delay transactions. Neglecting assignment clause language during negotiation can lead to the non-transferring party leveraging consent for concessions later.
content.expert_insight: Proactive negotiation of assignment clauses is essential to prevent future transactional hurdles and potential extortion by counterparties. Ensure clauses provide necessary flexibility for future corporate actions.
content.justification: Highlights the strategic importance and potential pitfalls of assignment clauses.
content.implication_company: Poorly negotiated assignment clauses can lead to delays, increased costs, and vulnerability to demands during M&A or reorganization.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may gain leverage if assignment clauses are restrictive, potentially delaying or complicating a company's corporate transactions.
content.source_insight: Based on internal playbook text.
content.text: Assignment clauses can become critical in a sale of business, acquisition or other similar transaction. Having an obligation to obtain consents for assigning contracts from present contract parties can complicate and potentially sidetrack the contemplated transaction. Failure to pay close attention to the language of the assignment clause while the contract is being negotiated may also create an opportunity for the nontransferring party to later extort concessions in return to its consent to the contract assignment.

content.verbatim_text: It is for these reasons important to make sure that each contract we conclude gives us the maximum flexibility to assign without the supplier’s consent to any succeeding entity to Zebracorp (in case of a reorganization), or at the minimum allow free assignment by Zebracorp to an affiliate (which accomplishes the same ability for re-organization if Zebracorp is acquired through a share purchase at the shareholder level).
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should ensure contracts allow maximum flexibility for assignment without supplier consent to any successor entity (for reorganization) or at least to an affiliate (for share purchase acquisitions).
content.expert_insight: Prioritize negotiating assignment clauses that grant broad rights for Zebracorp to transfer contracts to affiliates or successor entities without requiring counterparty consent, thus safeguarding future corporate restructuring and M&A activities.
content.conditions: Assignment to a succeeding entity (reorganization) or an affiliate (share purchase acquisition).
content.justification: To maintain flexibility for corporate reorganizations and acquisitions, avoiding complications and delays.
content.implication_company: Increased operational flexibility and reduced friction during M&A, reorganizations, or internal restructuring.
content.implication_supplier: May limit supplier's control over who they contract with if Zebracorp assigns to an affiliate or successor.
content.source_insight: Based on internal playbook text.
content.text: It is for these reasons important to make sure that each contract we conclude gives us the maximum flexibility to assign without the supplier’s consent to any succeeding entity to Zebracorp (in case of a reorganization), or at the minimum allow free assignment by Zebracorp to an affiliate (which accomplishes the same ability for re-organization if Zebracorp is acquired through a share purchase at the shareholder level).

content.verbatim_text: In the event the supplier/subcontractor refuses to grant us right to assign to an affiliate, then we should at the very minimum have a note saying that the approval for the assignment will not be “arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed”.
content.plain_text: If a supplier refuses free assignment to an affiliate, Zebracorp should insist on a clause stating that any required approval for assignment will not be arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed.
content.expert_insight: This fallback position ensures that even if direct assignment without consent isn't achieved, the supplier cannot use their consent right to obstruct legitimate business transfers without a valid reason.
content.conditions: Supplier/subcontractor refuses to grant free assignment rights to an affiliate.
content.justification: To prevent arbitrary obstruction of assignments when direct assignment without consent is not possible.
content.implication_company: Provides a legal basis to challenge unreasonable withholding of consent, reducing risk of delays or additional costs.
content.implication_supplier: Limits the supplier's discretion in denying assignment requests, requiring a reasonable justification.
content.source_insight: Based on internal playbook text.
content.text: In the event the supplier/subcontractor refuses to grant us right to assign to an affiliate, then we should at the very minimum have a note saying that the approval for the assignment will not be “arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed”.

content.verbatim_text: Our right to assign each contract should include also partial assignment of the contract. In many cases such partial assignment right is implicit from the right to assign the entire agreement, but it would be recommended to expressly agree on a right to assign the agreement either in its entirety or partially.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's assignment rights should explicitly include partial assignment of contracts, even if it's often implicitly covered by the right to assign the entire agreement.
content.expert_insight: Explicitly stating the right to partial assignment removes ambiguity and provides greater clarity and flexibility, particularly useful for divesting specific business lines or components.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: To ensure clarity and explicit flexibility for partial contract transfers, removing potential for dispute.
content.implication_company: Facilitates granular control over contract transfers, useful for divestitures or restructuring specific parts of the business.
content.implication_supplier: May require suppliers to manage contracts with multiple parties or accept partial transfers.
content.source_insight: Based on internal playbook text.
content.text: Our right to assign each contract should include also partial assignment of the contract. In many cases such partial assignment right is implicit from the right to assign the entire agreement, but it would be recommended to expressly agree on a right to assign the agreement either in its entirety or partially.

content.verbatim_text: Ideally we should also seek to secure a right to ‘split’ the respective contract, in case of divestment of a Zebracorp business line so that both Zebracorp and any third party acquirer of any specific Zebracorp business line will continue to be able to use the same contract.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should aim to secure the right to 'split' contracts during divestment of a business line, allowing both Zebracorp and the acquirer to continue using the same contract.
content.expert_insight: This provision is critical for maintaining business continuity and operational efficiency post-divestment, ensuring that both the divesting and acquiring entities retain access to essential contractual services or rights.
content.conditions: In case of divestment of a Zebracorp business line.
content.justification: To ensure business continuity for both Zebracorp and the acquirer of a divested business line.
content.implication_company: Enables smoother divestments by allowing shared use of critical contracts, avoiding the need for renegotiation or new contracts.
content.implication_supplier: May require the supplier to manage a single contract with two separate legal entities post-split.
content.source_insight: Based on internal playbook text.
content.text: Ideally we should also seek to secure a right to ‘split’ the respective contract, in case of divestment of a Zebracorp business line so that both Zebracorp and any third party acquirer of any specific Zebracorp business line will continue to be able to use the same contract.

content.verbatim_text: Please note that, when negotiating the assignment clause with our suppliers/subcontractors, we would not wish to agree to a mutual assignment right. This means that in most cases we would rather forego our right to assign than to agree on any language that would allow the supplier/subcontractor to freely assign the agreement to a third party without our consent.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should avoid agreeing to mutual assignment rights with suppliers/subcontractors. It is preferable to forgo Zebracorp's own right to assign rather than allowing suppliers to freely assign without Zebracorp's consent.
content.expert_insight: This is a strategic stance to protect Zebracorp from unknown or unqualified suppliers. The risk of a supplier assigning to an undesirable third party outweighs the benefit of Zebracorp's own free assignment rights in many cases.
content.conditions: When negotiating assignment clauses with suppliers/subcontractors.
content.justification: To prevent suppliers from substituting themselves with unvetted third parties, which would negate Zebracorp's supplier selection process and potentially compromise critical commitments.
content.implication_company: Maintains control over the quality and reliability of its supply chain, mitigating risks associated with unknown third-party suppliers.
content.implication_supplier: Restricts the supplier's ability to transfer their contractual obligations without Zebracorp's explicit approval.
content.source_insight: Based on internal playbook text.
content.text: Please note that, when negotiating the assignment clause with our suppliers/subcontractors, we would not wish to agree to a mutual assignment right. This means that in most cases we would rather forego our right to assign than to agree on any language that would allow the supplier/subcontractor to freely assign the agreement to a third party without our consent.

content.verbatim_text: This is because each of our suppliers have gone through a selection process where each supplier has been deemed financially and otherwise able to meet their eventual contractual commitments towards Zebracorp. Allowing the supplier to freely substitute itself to another third party would negate the entire selection process, and in worst case enable the supplier to effectively walk away from critical contractual commitments.
content.plain_text: The rationale for restricting supplier assignment is that each supplier undergoes a selection process to ensure their financial and operational capability. Free assignment by a supplier would undermine this process and could allow them to evade critical commitments.
content.expert_insight: This justification highlights the importance of maintaining control over the supplier relationship to safeguard Zebracorp's operational integrity and minimize supply chain risks.
content.justification: Explains why mutual assignment rights are undesirable from Zebracorp's perspective.
content.implication_company: Reinforces the importance of supplier vetting and the risks of uncontrolled assignments.
content.implication_supplier: Explains the basis for Zebracorp's restrictive stance on supplier assignment.
content.source_insight: Based on internal playbook text.
content.text: This is because each of our suppliers have gone through a selection process where each supplier has been deemed financially and otherwise able to meet their eventual contractual commitments towards Zebracorp. Allowing the supplier to freely substitute itself to another third party would negate the entire selection process, and in worst case enable the supplier to effectively walk away from critical contractual commitments.

content.verbatim_text: Also note that our right to assign the contract should not be made subject to us remaining jointly liable for the assigned contract together with the assignee. The assignment should be unconditional in the sense that Zebracorp will not accept liability for any commitments made by any third party assignee. The assignment should also provide a clean exit for Zebracorp in the sense that Zebracorp will not remain jointly liable under the assigned agreement with the new contracting party.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's assignment rights should be unconditional, meaning Zebracorp should not remain jointly liable with the assignee for the assigned contract or any commitments made by the third-party assignee. The assignment should provide a clean exit from liability.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical risk mitigation strategy. Zebracorp must ensure that once a contract is assigned, its liability for that contract ceases entirely, preventing residual or contingent liabilities from impacting future operations.
content.conditions: When assigning a contract.
content.justification: To ensure a clean exit from liability and prevent Zebracorp from being held responsible for the assignee's performance or commitments.
content.implication_company: Minimizes post-assignment liability, providing financial and legal certainty after divestitures or transfers.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier must look solely to the assignee for performance and liability post-assignment, assuming the assignee is a suitable replacement.
content.source_insight: Based on internal playbook text.
content.text: Also note that our right to assign the contract should not be made subject to us remaining jointly liable for the assigned contract together with the assignee. The assignment should be unconditional in the sense that Zebracorp will not accept liability for any commitments made by any third party assignee. The assignment should also provide a clean exit for Zebracorp in the sense that Zebracorp will not remain jointly liable under the assigned agreement with the new contracting party.

content.verbatim_text: When planning acquisitions or such other corporate transactions, the acquiring party will usually have to consider how it prefers to structure the transactions. The acquiring party can either elect to purchase the target company's assets (which enables the acquiring party to pick and choose only the assets and contracts they desire) or alternatively it may elect to acquire the entire company. In an asset sale, the need for contract-by-contract due diligence, would become particularly important since each contract needs to be specifically assigned in the context of asset sale. The acquiring party would generally be able to avoid such issues by electing to acquire the entire share capital of the target company (thereby making it a subsidiary of the acquiring entity) or by merging together with the target company. In the latter case (i.e. when the acquiring party obtains all outstanding shares in the target company and makes the acquired company its subsidiary), there is strictly speaking no need to obtain a consent for the assignment of the related contracts. This is because the contracts in themselves are not ‘assigned’ to any new legal entity but only the owner of the existing legal entity changes. Contrary to widely held belief, changes in ownership do not generally require the other contracting party’s consent. In companies whose shares are stock-listed the ownership changes each day the market is open.
content.plain_text: Corporate transactions involve choosing between asset purchases (requiring specific assignment and due diligence for each contract) or acquiring the entire company (share purchase or merger). Share purchases/mergers typically don't require consent for contract assignment because the legal entity remains, only ownership changes. Changes in ownership generally do not require counterparty consent.
content.expert_insight: This clarifies the distinction between asset and share acquisitions regarding contract assignment implications. Share acquisitions are generally preferred for contract continuity, but specific change of control clauses can override this general principle.
content.justification: Provides context on different acquisition structures and their impact on contract assignment requirements.
content.implication_company: Informs strategic decisions regarding M&A structure to minimize contract assignment hurdles. Highlights the importance of due diligence in asset sales.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware that a change in ownership of their contracting party (via share sale) does not automatically trigger assignment rights.
content.source_insight: Based on internal playbook text.
content.text: When planning acquisitions or such other corporate transactions, the acquiring party will usually have to consider how it prefers to structure the transactions. The acquiring party can either elect to purchase the target company's assets (which enables the acquiring party to pick and choose only the assets and contracts they desire) or alternatively it may elect to acquire the entire company. In an asset sale, the need for contract-by-contract due diligence, would become particularly important since each contract needs to be specifically assigned in the context of asset sale. The acquiring party would generally be able to avoid such issues by electing to acquire the entire share capital of the target company (thereby making it a subsidiary of the acquiring entity) or by merging together with the target company. In the latter case (i.e. when the acquiring party obtains all outstanding shares in the target company and makes the acquired company its subsidiary), there is strictly speaking no need to obtain a consent for the assignment of the related contracts. This is because the contracts in themselves are not ‘assigned’ to any new legal entity but only the owner of the existing legal entity changes. Contrary to widely held belief, changes in ownership do not generally require the other contracting party’s consent. In companies whose shares are stock-listed the ownership changes each day the market is open.

content.verbatim_text: An acquisition or a merger would in most countries serve to "vest" all assets and liabilities including contracts automatically to a merging and surviving entity or the acquiring party, as the case may be, by ‘operation of law’ without a need to obtain a consent from the opposing party.
content.plain_text: Assignment by operation of law occurs when an acquisition or merger automatically transfers (vests) all assets, liabilities, and contracts to the surviving or acquiring entity, without requiring consent from the other contracting party.
content.expert_insight: This concept is crucial for understanding how contracts are handled in statutory mergers or certain types of acquisitions, often bypassing standard assignment consent requirements unless explicitly contracted otherwise.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: An acquisition or a merger would in most countries serve to "vest" all assets and liabilities including contracts automatically to a merging and surviving entity or the acquiring party, as the case may be, by ‘operation of law’ without a need to obtain a consent from the opposing party.

content.verbatim_text: The parties are of course free to agree between themselves that a ownership change of certain magnitude (in e.g. affecting over 50 % of all outstanding shares) will require the other party’s consent.
content.plain_text: Contracting parties can agree that an ownership change beyond a certain threshold (e.g., over 50% of shares) will require the other party's consent, even if not required by operation of law.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the contractual override to statutory provisions. Parties can, and often do, include 'change of control' clauses that trigger consent requirements despite a legal entity's continuity.
content.justification: Clarifies that while operation of law may not require consent, parties can contractually mandate it.
content.implication_company: Must carefully review 'change of control' clauses in contracts, as they can impose consent requirements even for share acquisitions.
content.implication_supplier: Can negotiate to include 'change of control' clauses to maintain control over who they are contracting with, even if the legal entity remains the same.
content.source_insight: Based on internal playbook text.
content.text: The parties are of course free to agree between themselves that a ownership change of certain magnitude (in e.g. affecting over 50 % of all outstanding shares) will require the other party’s consent.

content.verbatim_text: “Any attempted assignment of this [Agreement] whether directly, by change in control or by operation of law, shall be ineffective unless effected with the other party’s prior written consent”.
content.plain_text: An example clause states that any assignment, whether direct, by change of control, or by operation of law, is ineffective without the other party's prior written consent.
content.expert_insight: This is a common, restrictive 'change of control' clause that Zebracorp should be wary of, as it can significantly complicate future corporate transactions.
content.justification: Provides an example of a restrictive assignment clause.
content.implication_company: Such clauses can severely hinder Zebracorp's ability to undergo mergers or acquisitions without obtaining numerous consents.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may include such clauses to retain control over their counterparty, particularly if the identity of the contracting party is critical.
content.source_insight: Based on internal playbook text.
content.text: “Any attempted assignment of this [Agreement] whether directly, by change in control or by operation of law, shall be ineffective unless effected with the other party’s prior written consent”.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp’s firm view is that assignment of contract by operation of law should not require the supplier’s consent, and in most cases we should reject any language that requires us to seek consent from other party in connection with transfer of agreement by operation of law.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's strong position is that assignment by operation of law should not require supplier consent. It should generally reject contract language mandating consent for such transfers.
content.expert_insight: This reflects Zebracorp's strategy to streamline M&A and corporate restructuring by avoiding unnecessary consent requirements that can delay or complicate transactions.
content.conditions: When negotiating assignment clauses, particularly concerning transfers by operation of law.
content.justification: Such provisions complicate mergers, acquisitions, and other transactions, impacting timing, cost, and ability to consummate a smooth transaction.
content.implication_company: Reduces friction and costs associated with mergers and acquisitions, allowing for smoother corporate restructuring.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers lose the right to consent to transfers that occur automatically by law, potentially impacting their relationship with the new entity.
content.source_insight: Based on internal playbook text.
content.text: Zebracorp’s firm view is that assignment of contract by operation of law should not require the supplier’s consent, and in most cases we should reject any language that requires us to seek consent from other party in connection with transfer of agreement by operation of law.

content.verbatim_text: This is largely due to the fact that these type of provisions are likely to cause complications when planning mergers, acquisitions or such other transactions. For example, if Zebracorp was planning on forming a merger with another company, we would work from the assumption that our contracts with our suppliers/subcontractors would be automatically transferred to the new merged entity by operation of law without the need seek consents from our supplier base. An assignment restriction described above is likely to impact the timing, cost and our ability to consummate a "smooth" merger or such other transaction.
content.plain_text: Restrictions on assignment by operation of law complicate mergers and acquisitions, affecting timing, cost, and the ability to execute smooth transactions. Zebracorp assumes contracts transfer automatically in mergers without supplier consent.
content.expert_insight: This justification underscores the practical impact of restrictive clauses on corporate strategy and operational efficiency, emphasizing the need for contractual terms that support, rather than hinder, M&A activities.
content.justification: Explains the negative implications of requiring consent for assignment by operation of law.
content.implication_company: Highlights the direct impact on M&A strategy and execution, emphasizing the need to avoid such restrictive clauses.
content.implication_supplier: Explains why Zebracorp will push back on clauses that require consent for transfers by operation of law.
content.source_insight: Based on internal playbook text.
content.text: This is largely due to the fact that these type of provisions are likely to cause complications when planning mergers, acquisitions or such other transactions. For example, if Zebracorp was planning on forming a merger with another company, we would work from the assumption that our contracts with our suppliers/subcontractors would be automatically transferred to the new merged entity by operation of law without the need seek consents from our supplier base. An assignment restriction described above is likely to impact the timing, cost and our ability to consummate a "smooth" merger or such other transaction.

content.verbatim_text: In those critical R&D contracts and the like where we do impose these very same assignment restrictions on our suppliers, it would be better to abandon the entire clause than to agree to mutual clause that would restrict Zebracorp from assigning the contract. The fact that Zebracorp is not willing to make these assignment provisions mutual can often be explained to the supplier by the asymmetric contractual relationship i.e. that of the customer and the supplier. In most cases, we can make the contract more palatable to the supplier by agreeing to allow the supplier transfer the contract by operation of law to any party that is not a direct competitor of Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: For critical R&D contracts where Zebracorp imposes assignment restrictions on suppliers, it's better to remove the clause entirely than to make it mutual and restrict Zebracorp. This non-mutuality can be justified by the customer-supplier asymmetry. To make it more acceptable to suppliers, allow them to transfer by operation of law to non-competitors of Zebracorp.
content.expert_insight: This guideline provides a pragmatic approach to balancing Zebracorp's need for control in critical R&D contexts with the need for fairness and negotiability. The 'non-competitor' carve-out is a smart compromise.
content.conditions: Applicable to critical R&D contracts where Zebracorp imposes assignment restrictions on suppliers.
content.justification: To avoid restricting Zebracorp's own assignment rights while still managing supplier risk in critical areas. Asymmetric relationship justifies non-mutuality.
content.implication_company: Maintains Zebracorp's flexibility while protecting critical R&D interests. Offers a negotiation tactic to appease suppliers.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may still be restricted but are offered a concession for transfers by operation of law, provided the assignee is not a Zebracorp competitor.
content.source_insight: Based on internal playbook text.
content.text: In those critical R&D contracts and the like where we do impose these very same assignment restrictions on our suppliers, it would be better to abandon the entire clause than to agree to mutual clause that would restrict Zebracorp from assigning the contract. The fact that Zebracorp is not willing to make these assignment provisions mutual can often be explained to the supplier by the asymmetric contractual relationship i.e. that of the customer and the supplier. In most cases, we can make the contract more palatable to the supplier by agreeing to allow the supplier transfer the contract by operation of law to any party that is not a direct competitor of Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: Under UK laws, an assignment of rights under a contract is normally restricted solely to the benefits of the contract. Where a party wishes to transfer both the benefit and burden of the contract without any residual liability (as is usually the case), the assignment of the contract would generally needs to be done by way of a novation.
content.plain_text: Under UK law, assignment typically transfers only contractual benefits. To transfer both benefits and burdens without residual liability, a novation is generally required.
content.expert_insight: This highlights a key distinction in UK contract law. Simple assignment in the UK does not automatically transfer obligations, making novation essential for a complete transfer of a contract with all its rights and duties.
content.justification: Explains the specific legal implications of assignment vs. novation under UK law.
content.implication_company: Crucial for Zebracorp to understand when dealing with UK-governed contracts to ensure full transfer of obligations and release from liability.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers under UK law must ensure novation is used if they intend to fully transfer their contractual position.
content.source_insight: Based on internal playbook text.
content.text: Under UK laws, an assignment of rights under a contract is normally restricted solely to the benefits of the contract. Where a party wishes to transfer both the benefit and burden of the contract without any residual liability (as is usually the case), the assignment of the contract would generally needs to be done by way of a novation.

content.verbatim_text: Where a party wishes to transfer both the benefit and burden of the contract without any residual liability (as is usually the case), the assignment of the contract would generally needs to be done by way of a novation.
content.plain_text: Novation is the process required, particularly under UK law, to transfer both the benefits and burdens of a contract, ensuring no residual liability for the original party.
content.expert_insight: Novation effectively creates a new contract between the remaining party and the new party, extinguishing the original contract. This is distinct from assignment, which only transfers rights.

content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A

content.text: Where a party wishes to transfer both the benefit and burden of the contract without any residual liability (as is usually the case), the assignment of the contract would generally needs to be done by way of a novation.

content.verbatim_text: For this reason, when the agreement is governed by UK laws, it is useful to specifically mention that the agreement is not only assigned but also novated, and the transfer of the rights and obligations may require the execution of a specific novation agreement.
content.plain_text: When a contract is governed by UK law, it is advisable to explicitly state that the agreement is both assigned and novated, potentially requiring a separate novation agreement for the transfer of rights and obligations.
content.expert_insight: This is a best practice for UK-governed contracts to ensure a complete and legally sound transfer of the entire contractual relationship, including liabilities.
content.conditions: Agreement is governed by UK laws.
content.justification: To ensure both benefits and burdens, and full release from liability, are transferred under UK law.
content.implication_company: Ensures full legal transfer and release from liability for UK-governed contracts, preventing residual obligations.
content.implication_supplier: Clarifies the legal mechanism for transferring contracts under UK law, ensuring proper documentation.
content.source_insight: Based on internal playbook text.
content.text: For this reason, when the agreement is governed by UK laws, it is useful to specifically mention that the agreement is not only assigned but also novated, and the transfer of the rights and obligations may require the execution of a specific novation agreement.

content.verbatim_text: Please speak to a member of the Legal & Compliance team to obtain the appropriate templates/language.
content.plain_text: Consult the Legal & Compliance team for appropriate templates/language regarding novation.
content.expert_insight: Always seek expert legal advice for complex contractual transfers like novation, especially when dealing with specific jurisdictional requirements.
content.justification: Ensures correct legal procedures and documentation are used for novation.
content.implication_company: Promotes compliance and reduces legal risk by using approved templates and language.
